
Do we want to have derivative code in `third_party/` or do we want to reserve that path for actual (git) submodules, kept verbatim? Why not put the new files somewhere else on the `src/core` hierarchy even if they are based in external work?

Sorry for a batch of post review changes here. Ran into trouble fixing the bazel build here and in fixing it, it seemed to be most simple to just completely remove the grpc dependency from the new submodule (I stopped using grpc's sockaddr utilities). The changes to `address_sorting.c` involved a batch of re-typed parameters and names. The bazel build is likely not completely fixed yet but it passes locally now.

Thanks for doing this! --- Reviewed 6 of 16 files at r1, 10 of 14 files at r7, 4 of 4 files at r8. Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 9 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 111 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb5uRBp7C6KtmaEZUu-r4-111:-Kyb8rq9gSpWjPrJ7Nnc:b-sry5h4) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/5121766c866dab193ad7daed889049759eabf1c9/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L111)):*
Previously, apolcyn wrote…
whoops that was a mistaken update, fixed
I think `PRIuPTR` is more appropriate than `PRIdPTR` for `size_t`. Also, let's use `GPR_DEBUG` instead of `GPR_INFO` for these two log messages. --- *[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 120 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb89hAGftWSPC-TKii:-Kyb89hAGftWSPC-TKij:b1kall5) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L120)):* > ```cpp > } > > void grpc_cares_wrapper_address_sorting_sort(grpc_lb_addresses* lb_addrs) { > ``` Given that the new address sorting code won't build under Windows, I think calling it from this file will cause problems. @nicolasnoble has #12416 in progress to allow the c-ares resolver to build under Windows, and it does that by providing a Windows version of grpc_ares_ev_driver_posix.cc, but the code in this file is expected to work for both. I think we should move this code into a file called address_sort_posix.cc, so that we can provide an alternative version for Windows in address_sort_windows.cc. That version might be a no-op, or it might do some Windows-specific thing. Please work with Nico to figure out the right approach here. --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.c, line 58 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb78IdbanEfT305jye:-Kyb78IdbanEfT305jyf:b-y2d65k) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.c#L58)):* > const int kIPv6AddrScopeSiteLocal = 2; > const int kIPv6AddrScopeGlobal = 3; Why are these not static? --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h, line 55 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb6VAtHKPurHsDWHFp:-Kyb6VAtHKPurHsDWHFq:b-6z6iv8) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h#L55)):* > ```objc > } address_sorting_address; > > typedef struct address_sorting_sortable { > ``` What does this struct represent? It's not obvious from an initial read, so it's definitely worth a comment. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-:-KybBVoRb0r-cE1gx7n8:bxgavm9)*

Review status: 10 of 23 files reviewed at latest revision, 9 unresolved discussions. --- *[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 120 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb89hAGftWSPC-TKii:-KycRubmMU0cQedDccaW:bplmk5d) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L120)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Given that the new address sorting code won't build under Windows, I think calling it from this file will cause problems. @nicolasnoble has #12416 in progress to allow the c-ares resolver to build under Windows, and it does that by providing a Windows version of grpc_ares_ev_driver_posix.cc, but the code in this file is expected to work for both. I think we should move this code into a file called address_sort_posix.cc, so that we can provide an alternative version for Windows in address_sort_windows.cc. That version might be a no-op, or it might do some Windows-specific thing. Please work with Nico to figure out the right approach here.
The latest update is my current idea to address this. It handles build portabilityy within the address sorting submodule (I split out the socket functions into platform specific files, added a portability config header to handle the sockaddr types on windows, and used more portable types in a few places. Windows should build but not work at runtime now. cc @nicolasnoble about this. --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.c, line 58 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb78IdbanEfT305jye:-KycRjuno3CXKH0oQmnx:b4su2gi) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.c#L58)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
> const int kIPv6AddrScopeSiteLocal = 2; > const int kIPv6AddrScopeGlobal = 3; Why are these not static?
fixed, that was a mistake --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h, line 55 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-Kyb6VAtHKPurHsDWHFp:-KycRcqSg261WVZUi4cd:b-obl2ay) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/3c3caacb315a853945829257eaefd5ce06fbf698/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h#L55)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
What does this struct represent? It's not obvious from an initial read, so it's definitely worth a comment.
fixed, added comment to explain --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290)*

Previously, apolcyn wrote…
The latest update is my current idea to address this. It handles build portabilityy within the address sorting submodule (I split out the socket functions into platform specific files, added a portability config header to handle the sockaddr types on windows, and used more portable types in a few places. Windows should build but not work at runtime now. cc @nicolasnoble about this.
Let's make sure we have a strategy for how we're going to do the address sorting on Windows. If we're going to use the same general code but need different socket functions, then this approach seems reasonable (modulo making sure the API you've defined for the socket functions will work on Windows). But if we need to use a completely different implementation on Windows, then we'll need a different abstraction. It's also worth considering how this will work for Node. @nicolasnoble is also the right person to talk to about that; he owns the task of adding Node support to the c-ares resolver, although he hasn't started that yet. Please make sure you chat with him and figure out the overall strategy here. Thanks! --- *[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 37 at r19](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-KyvK_we9uKMeDaXW9-_:-KyvK_wfswgIwya-lPhx:betcrg0) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/864b6f516ee8a018b2018219f273c91af983f764/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L37)):* > ```cpp > #include > > #include > ``` See my comment elsewhere about using quotes instead of angle brackets. --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h, line 77 at r19](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-KyvLP-oXF3ep6ddKMVE:-KyvLP-oXF3ep6ddKMVF:b-j8875x) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/864b6f516ee8a018b2018219f273c91af983f764/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h#L77)):* > ```objc > /* The socket factory interface is exposed only for testing */ > typedef struct { > int (*socket)(struct address_sorting_socket_factory* factory, int domain, > ``` This interface may not be sufficiently generic for Windows. I don't think sockets are simple integers on Windows. But @nicolasnoble will know better than I do. --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h, line 80 at r19](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-KyvLJaG_Ya6T72b2B_k:-KyvLJaG_Ya6T72b2B_l:b-hjbwsf) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/864b6f516ee8a018b2018219f273c91af983f764/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h#L80)):* > ```objc > int type, int protocol); > int (*connect)(struct address_sorting_socket_factory* factory, int sockfd, > const char* addr, size_t addrlen); > ``` Why `char` instead of `void`? --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h, line 82 at r19](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-KyvLM8hvBwOZP_RNIA5:-KyvLM8hvBwOZP_RNIA6:brhumzt) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/864b6f516ee8a018b2018219f273c91af983f764/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting.h#L82)):* > ```objc > const char* addr, size_t addrlen); > int (*getsockname)(struct address_sorting_socket_factory* factory, int sockfd, > char* addr, size_t* addrlen); > ``` Same here. --- *[third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting_windows.c, line 52 at r19](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290#-KyvLu_XxWkRGjXXodJg:-KyvLu_XxWkRGjXXodJh:b2j1qw) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/864b6f516ee8a018b2018219f273c91af983f764/third_party/address_sorting/address_sorting_windows.c#L52)):* > ```C > #include > > /* TODO : Fill in these functions; get address sorting functionality to work on > ``` It's probably not necessary to include the Winodws file in this PR; Nico can add it to his PR that adds support for Windows. All we need to do here is to make sure that the API can support a Windows implementation. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13290)*
